description: Contains information related to the accounting period, including corresponding fiscal year, beginning date and ending date. The table captures the time range within a specific reporting period and year, in which business transactions and entries are accumulated into financial statements and other reports.
Fiscal year in which the calendar date occurs.\nThe year shall be shown in four digits as YYYY, which is part of the extended format and the YYYY-MM-DD from ISO 8601-1.
Accounting period in which the calendar date occurs.\nEXAMPLE   W1-W53 for weekly periods, M1-M12 for monthly periods, Q1-Q4 for quarterly periods, from any beginning date to any ending date.
Calendar beginning date of the current accounting period.
Calendar ending date of the current accounting period.
Contains the details of a bank account.
Number of the account opened in an institution (e.g. bank, financial institution, settlement centre).\nISO 13616-2 is recommended if applicable.
Name of the account opened in an institution (e.g. bank, financial institution, settlement centre).
Code for the financial institution (in accordance with ISO 9362 or ISO 17442).\nISO 17442 is preferred. One reason is that the bank branch identifier will not change due to location movement.
Full name of the institution (e.g. bank, financial institution, settlement centre).
Code for the institution's branch.
Full name of the institution's branch.
Country code where the branch is physically located (in accordance with ISO 3166-1).
Sub-region within a country.\nEXAMPLE   A state in the US, a province in Canada.
Indicates whether the bank account is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

The information of the bill type (e.g. bank draft, commercial draft, promissory note, check). Bills are frequently used in the business cycle of sales and purchase, as evidence of debt, payment and/or settlement instrument.
Code for the bill type.\nEXAMPLE   004 is bank draft, 005 is promissory note, 006 is check.
Name of the bill type.\nEXAMPLE   Bank draft, commercial draft, promissory note and check.
Indicates whether the bill type is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

The fields in the Base Business Segment Hierarchy are used to capture the relationships between the individual organization units. The table assumes a one to one relationship and captures the data necessary to consolidate transactions occurring for child level organizational units into higher level organizational structures (for example, business unit to division).
Code for the parent business segment.
Code for the child business segment.

Contains the information about GL accounts, including name, description, type and hierarchy. This table is level 1. When it is cross-referred by other table(s), consistency shall apply. For example, in this table, the value of GL Account Number is 101, the value of GL Account Name is cash, and the value of Balance Debit Or Credit is D. If the value of GL Account Number in GL Trial Balance table is 101, then the Amount corresponding with cash account (101) must be debit.
Number of the GL account.
Name of the GL account.
Label or description associated with the GL Account Number.
Financial statement caption that represents a related group of accounts.\nEXAMPLE   Cash and cash equivalents, AP, cost of sales.\nThe caption can be at the trial balance level.
Type of account.\nEXAMPLE   Assets, liabilities, equity, revenues, expenses.
Subtype of the account.\nEXAMPLE   Current assets are the subtype of assets.
Corresponding level for account number in the account hierarchy.\nEXAMPLE   1 is assets, 2 is the account subtype current assets.

Number of the parent account in an account hierarchy.\nThis is provided to allow more than the predefined levels of the hierarchy in the Base Chart Of Accounts table.\nWhen Parent GL Account Number is the highest level, its value can be set to the default value (e.g. set to NULL).

Indicates whether the natural balance of the account is a debit or credit balance by indicating D or C, where assets and expenses have a natural balance of debit, and liabilities, equity and revenues have a natural balance of credit.
Indicates whether the GL account is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).
Contains the information of the currency.
Code for the currency (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Name of the currency in the accounting and/or ERP system.

Unit of recorded value that is a division of the respective unit of currency.\nMinor unit shows the decimal relationship between such a unit and the currency itself (in accordance with ISO 4217). Number 0 means that there is no minor unit for that currency. Numbers 1, 2, 3, etc. signify a ratio of 10:1, 100:1, 1 000:1, etc., respectively.\nEXAMPLE   The US cent is a one hundredth part of the US dollar. The GB penny is a one hundredth part of the pound sterling. The minor unit number for both is 2.
Indicates whether Currency Code is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

An Account Segment is a customized file item, which includes the information of the customized account segments that are not fixed account segments and no other table contains their description information (e.g. region type). This table is used together with the Base Customized Account Value.

Code for the customized account segment that audit data need to be used.\nThis does not include the fixed account segment having been identified.\nEXAMPLE   Unlike customer, budget information is not included in the Base module as an individual table, therefore budget can be identified as a customized account segment.
Customized account segment name that audit data need to be used.\nEXAMPLE   Budget records, planned revenue, expenditure.

Customized account segment description that audit data need to be used.\nEXAMPLE   Budget can be described as the annual plan of aggregated fiscal revenue and expenditure for a state, which is verified and approved through legal procedures.

Encoding rules of the value of a customized account segment.\nIf the encoding rule has a hierarchy feature, each level is separated by "-".\nEXAMPLE   Budget (with a 1-digit code, e.g. 1) can be subdivided into financial budget (with a 2-digit code, e.g. 01) and construction budget (with a 2-digit code, e.g. 05), with the financial budget containing budgeted revenue (with a 2-digit code, e.g. 03) and budgeted expenditure (with a 2-digit code, e.g. 04), which are the third-level segments. In this case, the Customized Account Encoding Rule is 1-2-2.
Whether or not the table value has a hierarchy feature.\nEXAMPLE   1 is yes, 0 is no.
Indicates whether the Customized Account Segment Code is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.
Contains the information from the customized account segment value.
Code for the customized account segment value.\nIf the Customized Account Encoding Rule is 1-2-2, the corresponding budget-financial budget-budgeted expenditure is 10104.
Associated with the Base Customized Account Segment table.
Name of the account segment value of each file.\nEXAMPLE   Budget-financial budget-budgeted expenditure.
Detailed description of the account segment value.
Code for the parent customized account segment value.
Level of the current value in the file structure.\nEXAMPLE   1 is the highest.
Contains the personnel information of the employee in an independent accounting unit.
Unique identifier for an employee.

Code for the employee. Each employee has only one code. If someone has part-time jobs in multiple departments, there will be more than one record with different Employee ID in this table. The part time status will be reflected in Employee Type Code.
The name of the employee.
Indicates whether one employee is active or inactive.\nAn employee can become inactive due to various reasons (e.g taking a sabbatical).
Code for the employee type.\nEXAMPLE 004 is an on-the job employee, 005 is a retired employee, 006 is a deceased employee, 007 is a part-time employee.
Name of the employee type.\nEXAMPLE Employed, retired, probation, part-time.
Code for department rosters. \nEXAMPLE The department name is Information Technology department, the code is 0018.
Job title of the person in an accounting unit.\nEXAMPLE Accounting manager.
Highest academic degree acquired.\nEXAMPLE Doctor, Master.
Employment date of the employee.
Termination date of the employee from which the labor contract was no longer valid, or the employee no longer works in this department.
System user ID associated with the employee.
Contains information relevant to the GL journal entry type (e.g. cash receipts, cash disbursements).
Code for the journal entry type.\nEXAMPLE   004 is a cash receipt entry, 005 is a cash disbursement entry, 006 is a non-cash entry.

Name of the journal entry type.\nThis is usually categorized by business to satisfy an internal control need and/or to facilitate sorting and querying.\nEXAMPLE   Journal entries can be classified based on whether the transaction involves cash. In this case, there can be a cash receipt entry, cash disbursement entry and non-cash entry of adjusting that is the recording of interest revenue earned and wages payable, estimation that is the recording depreciation, and bad-debt expenses, and/or correction that makes entries to counteract the effects of errors found in the GL.
Abbreviation of the journal entry type.
Indicates whether the Journal Entry type is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.
Contains information of the measurement unit (UOM) used in the modules of GL, Sales, Purchase, Inventory and PPE.
Code of the measurement unit.
Name of the measurement unit for measuring the quantity of the material, etc.
Abbreviation of the measurement unit's name.\nEXAMPLE   Kilogram is kg, square metre is sq.m.
Indicates whether the Unit of Measurement Code is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

Contains the details of the payment term, which is applied and referenced in the Purchase and Sales modules. The payment term refers to the condition of a sale/purchase agreement and is related to how the customer will pay (type of credit instrument), and especially how much time is allowed for payment (credit period) and discount (cash discount and discount period).

Code for the payment term.\nEXAMPLE   Terms of 2/10, net 60 are quoted. This means that customers have 60 days from the invoice date to pay the full amount. However, if payment is made within 10 days, a 2 % cash discount can be taken.
The full name of the payment term.
Number of the lines according to the Payment Term Code value.\nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
Detailed description of the payment term's line.\nEXAMPLE   Payment due date, discount days, discount percentage.
Indicates whether the payment term is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

Contains industry and software version information. This table contains information related to the profile of the data being collected. For example, when we extract the financial data of 2016 from an auditee using SAP XXX ERP System in 2017.1.16, there should be a record with the Profile Name "XXX 2016", Fiscal Year "2016", Developer Name "SAP", Software Name "SAP S/4", Software Version "2.0", Functional Currency "CNY", Standard Version "ISO 21378", Extracted Date "2017-01-16".
Number of the current data collection.\nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
Name of the current data collection.
Fiscal year in which the calendar date occurs.\nThe date shall be shown as YYYY-MM-DD in the extended format. The YYYY indicates a four-digit year (in accordance with ISO 8601-1).
Legal name of an accounting entity.
Corresponding industry name under a superior sector code.
Name of accounting and/or ERP system software developer.
Name of accounting and/or ERP system software products.
Accounting and/or ERP system software version.
Functional or group currency used in accounting and/or ERP system software (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Standard issuing number of the standard(s) with which the current output files are consistent.\nEXAMPLE   ISO 21378.
Date of the data extraction.

Indicates the difference between the local time and UTC of a day.\nThe representation of the difference can be expressed in hours and minutes, or hours only. The Time Zone shall be shown as \xb1hh:mm in the extended format (in accordance with ISO 8601-1).\nEXAMPLE   Newfoundland's time zone is -03:30, Beijing's time zone is +08:00.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

Contains the detailed information related to the project (e.g. construction project, government or business-funded research project). Projects are commonly administrated separately and could be subject to being audit in accordance with regulatory and/or managerial requirements. The audit of a project is a thorough examination of the management, execution, methodology, procedures, records, budgets, expenditures, and the degree of completion. It is referenced in several modules including GL, AR, AP and Inventory.
Unique identifier for the project.
Code of the project.
Name of the project related to operation and administration.
Beginning date of the project.
Ending date of the project.
Indicates whether the project is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

Unique identifier that refers to the selection criteria for selecting tables and fields. The permitted values of Selection ID and the associated selection criteria should be determined by mutual agreement between the auditor and the auditee.
Unique identifier that refers to the separately defined criteria for selecting tables and fields.
Start date of the selected period (YYYY-MM-DD). The start time is always "00:00:00".
End date of the selected period (YYYY-MM-DD). The end time is always "23:59:59".

Contains information on methods used to settle transactions. Businesses can adopt various methods to settle transactions and transfer money, especially in sales and purchase activities. Typical settlement methods include cash settlements, issuing bills, using credit cards, bank remittances and bank collections.

Code for the settlement method.\nVarious methods can be used to settle transactions and transfer money.\nEXAMPLE   001 for cash, 002 for bills, 003 for credit card, 004 for remittance, 005 for bank collection.
Name of the settlement method.\nEXAMPLE   Cash settlement, issuing bills, credit card, bank remittance, bank collection.
Indicates whether the settlement method is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.
Contains regulatory information related to taxes, including regulator country, region, name and role.
Code of the regulator or jurisdiction.
Country code where the regulator is located (in accordance with ISO 3166-1).
Sub-region within a country.\nEXAMPLE   A state in the US, a province in Canada.
Name of the regulator for which tax is withheld or accrued.
Role of the regulator, whether federal, regional or local.
GL account used to reflect the amounts payable to the regulator.
GL account used to reflect the accruals due to the regulator.
GL account used to reflect the expenses related to the regulator.
ID assigned/generated by the regulator for the reporting organization to the regulator.
Code for the reporting organization.
Indicates whether the Regulator Code is active or inactive.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

Contains detailed information on tax types used by the business. The tables in AR, Sales, AP and Purchase modules contain 4 tax types, which can meet the requirements in most cases of the business. Tax types could be tax in country level, state level, county level or in local level, or could be tax related to a transaction (e.g. sales tax, value added tax, tariff).
Code used to refer to this tax type, used as a key or cross-reference in files.\nEXAMPLE   004 is the income tax, 005 is the tariff, 006 is the value added tax.
Name of the tax type.\nEXAMPLE   Income tax, tariff, value added tax.
Code for the regulator for this tax.
Description of the tax type.
Description of the tax code, which is a sub-division of the tax type.\nEXAMPLE   Lower percentage applicable for common goods.
Default percentage for this combination of tax type and tax code.\nCan use the Extracted Date from the Base Profile table.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).
Contains the user information of accounting and/or ERP system.

Unique identifier for individuals entering transactions into the accounting and/or ERP system.
This field is used to join information in this table to other tables based on fields such as Created User ID, 
Last Modified User ID, 
Approved User ID and Posted User ID.
Indicates whether the status of the user is active or inactive.\nA user can become inactive due to retirement, dismissal or termination, etc.\nEXAMPLE   1 is active, 0 is inactive.
Modified date of the user's activation or termination status.
Name of the user.
Job title of the person in the system.\nEXAMPLE   System manager.
Code for department rosters.\nEXAMPLE   The department name is Information Technology department, the code is 0018.
Free-form description of the individual's functional role or primary responsibility.\nEXAMPLE   Responsibility related to managing the information of AP in the system.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.

The amount of Tax included in the transaction. Recorded in local currency.

The GL account number on which the debit side of the Tax transaction has been posted.

Contains the code and name for the account segment, as well as the GL Account Number to which the account segment is related. Account Segment provides additional information for particular GL Accounts (e.g. the AR contains the information regarding supplier, customer, employee, and project). Such information would be treated as an Account Segment below A/R, thus resulting in a lengthy account structure. The Account Segment structure is therefore defined as a set to record related information, which efficiently stops account names and numbers from becoming too long and too complex. Account Segment is more flexible to capture the complicated information.
Number of the GL account. \nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

Number of the Account Segment.
Case 1: If the value of this field is 0, the record is used to explain a fixed account segment that is distinguished by the Account Segment Name of the record.
Case 2: If the value of this field is 5, the record is used to explain the No.5 field of Account Segment X, named Account Segment 5 in the tables, such as GL Details.
This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

Name of the Account Segment.\nCase 1: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 0, the field contains the name of a fixed account segment, such as Account Segment Employee.\nCase 2: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 5, the field value should be the name of a customized account segment, such as welfare expenditure.

Table corresponding to the account segment. 
Case 1: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 0, the field contains the table name corresponding to the fixed account segment, such as Base Employee for Account Segment Employee.
Case 2: If the value of the Account Segment Number is larger than 0, and no other table besides Base Customized Account Segment contains the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be Base Customized Account Segment.
Case 3: If the value of the Account Segment Number is larger than 0, and there is a table containing the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be the table's name, such as Base Customer.
Detailed description of the Account Segment Name.
Code for the customized account segment.
Contains all of the journal entry header data for each transaction (e.g. Journal ID, Accounting Period, Effective Date). This table should be at the journal header level.
Unique identifier for each journal entry.
Number of the journal entry (e.g. including serial number, document type, date).
Fiscal year in which the Effective Date occurs.\nThe year shall be shown in four digits as YYYY, which is part of the extended format and the YYYY-MM-DD from ISO 8601-1.
Accounting period in which the Effective Date occurs.\nEXAMPLE   W1-W53 for weekly periods, M1-M12 for monthly periods, Q1-Q4 for quarterly periods, from any beginning date to any ending date.
Code for the source from which the journal entry originated.\nEXAMPLE   Sales journal, cash receipts journal, general journal, payroll journal, accountant manual entry, spreadsheet.

Date of the journal entry, no matter when the entry is received or created.\nThis sometimes refers to the accounting date or accounting effective date.\nEXAMPLE   If the user wants to see the financial results for the period ending March 5, 20XX, the journal entry may be created on any day during the open period and be assigned to the period ending March 5, 20XX.
Description of the entire journal entry as described by the journal entry header.

Contains all of the journal entry details for each transaction (e.g. associated journal entry ID, associated account number, debits or credits associated with the journal entry line). This table should be at the journal entry line level.
Number of the line within a journal entry.\nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
Code for the journal entry type.
Description of the individual line within the journal entry.
Number of the GL account.

Number of the bill.\nA bill usually includes bank drafts, promissory notes and checks. A bill may be issued by the drawer who agreed upon themselves or entrusts the drawee at sight. A specified date to the payee or bearer unconditionally pays a certain amount of securities.\nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
Type of bill.\nEXAMPLE   Bank drafts, promissory notes, checks.
Date of the bill.
Quantity of items referenced in the journal entry line.\nWhen the GL Account Number is for inventories or fixed assets, this field is effective. If not, this field is NULL.
Code for the physical measurement scale for the inventory and Property, Plant and Equipment referred to as a "unit of measurement (UOM)".

Per unit price of the inventory or PPE.\nThis field is associated with Quantity and Amount.\nEXAMPLE   If the account is inventory or PPE, Quantity can be multiplied by Unit Price to get total line Amount.
Code value or indicator of the settlement method used for cash receipt from customers (i.e. sales) and cash payment to suppliers (i.e. purchase).\nEXAMPLE   Check, wire transfer, cash.
Indicates whether the amount is a credit or a debit.\nEXAMPLE   C is credit, D is debit.

Indicates whether this entry is a reversal or to be reversed.\nEXAMPLE   1 is the entry is a reversal, 2 is the entry is being reversed, an empty (" ") is none of the above or system-generated indicators.
When the Reversal Indicator = 1, this field identifies the Journal ID of the entry being reversed.
Sign of cancellation of a journal entry already formed but not yet posted.\nEXAMPLE   0 is entry is not cancelled, 1 is entry is cancelled.
Related amount expressed in functional, transaction, reporting and local currency.
Different types of amounts with corresponding currency code.
Amount recorded in the functional or group currency.
Code of the functional or group currency (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Amount recorded in the transaction currency.
The code of currency used in the actual transaction (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Amount recorded in the reporting currency.
The code of currency used for non-consolidated reporting (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Amount recorded in the local currency.
The code of currency used for local country reporting requirements  (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Information about the data was approved within the system.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.
Information about the data that was created into the system.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.
Information about the data that was posted.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.
Account Segment Employee, Account Segment Project, Account Segment Bank Account are commonly used Account Segment.

Contains the code and name for the account segment, as well as the GL Account Number to which the account segment is related. Account Segment provides additional information for particular GL Accounts (e.g. the AR contains the information regarding supplier, customer, employee, and project). Such information would be treated as an Account Segment below A/R, thus resulting in a lengthy account structure. The Account Segment structure is therefore defined as a set to record related information, which efficiently stops account names and numbers from becoming too long and too complex. Account Segment is more flexible to capture the complicated information.
Number of the GL account. \nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

Number of the Account Segment.
Case 1: If the value of this field is 0, the record is used to explain a fixed account segment that is distinguished by the Account Segment Name of the record.
Case 2: If the value of this field is 5, the record is used to explain the No.5 field of Account Segment X, named Account Segment 5 in the tables, such as GL Details.
This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

Name of the Account Segment.\nCase 1: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 0, the field contains the name of a fixed account segment, such as Account Segment Employee.\nCase 2: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 5, the field value should be the name of a customized account segment, such as welfare expenditure.

Table corresponding to the account segment. 
Case 1: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 0, the field contains the table name corresponding to the fixed account segment, such as Base Employee for Account Segment Employee.
Case 2: If the value of the Account Segment Number is larger than 0, and no other table besides Base Customized Account Segment contains the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be Base Customized Account Segment.
Case 3: If the value of the Account Segment Number is larger than 0, and there is a table containing the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be the table's name, such as Base Customer.
Detailed description of the Account Segment Name.
Code for the customized account segment.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

Contains all of the journal entry details for each transaction (e.g. associated journal entry ID, associated account number, debits or credits associated with the journal entry line). This table should be at the journal entry line level.
Number of the line within a journal entry.\nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
Code for the journal entry type.
Description of the individual line within the journal entry.
Number of the GL account.

Number of the bill.\nA bill usually includes bank drafts, promissory notes and checks. A bill may be issued by the drawer who agreed upon themselves or entrusts the drawee at sight. A specified date to the payee or bearer unconditionally pays a certain amount of securities.\nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.
Type of bill.\nEXAMPLE   Bank drafts, promissory notes, checks.
Date of the bill.
Quantity of items referenced in the journal entry line.\nWhen the GL Account Number is for inventories or fixed assets, this field is effective. If not, this field is NULL.
Code for the physical measurement scale for the inventory and Property, Plant and Equipment referred to as a "unit of measurement (UOM)".

Per unit price of the inventory or PPE.\nThis field is associated with Quantity and Amount.\nEXAMPLE   If the account is inventory or PPE, Quantity can be multiplied by Unit Price to get total line Amount.
Code value or indicator of the settlement method used for cash receipt from customers (i.e. sales) and cash payment to suppliers (i.e. purchase).\nEXAMPLE   Check, wire transfer, cash.
Indicates whether the amount is a credit or a debit.\nEXAMPLE   C is credit, D is debit.

Indicates whether this entry is a reversal or to be reversed.\nEXAMPLE   1 is the entry is a reversal, 2 is the entry is being reversed, an empty (" ") is none of the above or system-generated indicators.
When the Reversal Indicator = 1, this field identifies the Journal ID of the entry being reversed.
Sign of cancellation of a journal entry already formed but not yet posted.\nEXAMPLE   0 is entry is not cancelled, 1 is entry is cancelled.
Related amount expressed in functional, transaction, reporting and local currency.
Different types of amounts with corresponding currency code.
Amount recorded in the functional or group currency.
Code of the functional or group currency (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Amount recorded in the transaction currency.
The code of currency used in the actual transaction (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Amount recorded in the reporting currency.
The code of currency used for non-consolidated reporting (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Amount recorded in the local currency.
The code of currency used for local country reporting requirements  (in accordance with ISO 4217).
Information about the data was approved within the system.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.
Information about the data that was created into the system.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.
Information about the data that was posted.
Activity information.
The unique identifier for the person who did the activity.
The date of activity. This should be a system generated date (rather than user-created date), when possible. This is sometimes referred to as the creation date.
The time of activity.
Account Segment Employee, Account Segment Project, Account Segment Bank Account are commonly used Account Segment.

Contains the code and name for the account segment, as well as the GL Account Number to which the account segment is related. Account Segment provides additional information for particular GL Accounts (e.g. the AR contains the information regarding supplier, customer, employee, and project). Such information would be treated as an Account Segment below A/R, thus resulting in a lengthy account structure. The Account Segment structure is therefore defined as a set to record related information, which efficiently stops account names and numbers from becoming too long and too complex. Account Segment is more flexible to capture the complicated information.
Number of the GL account. \nThis number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

Number of the Account Segment.
Case 1: If the value of this field is 0, the record is used to explain a fixed account segment that is distinguished by the Account Segment Name of the record.
Case 2: If the value of this field is 5, the record is used to explain the No.5 field of Account Segment X, named Account Segment 5 in the tables, such as GL Details.
This number is generated either by manual input or by the system.

Name of the Account Segment.\nCase 1: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 0, the field contains the name of a fixed account segment, such as Account Segment Employee.\nCase 2: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 5, the field value should be the name of a customized account segment, such as welfare expenditure.

Table corresponding to the account segment. 
Case 1: If the value of the Account Segment Number of the record is 0, the field contains the table name corresponding to the fixed account segment, such as Base Employee for Account Segment Employee.
Case 2: If the value of the Account Segment Number is larger than 0, and no other table besides Base Customized Account Segment contains the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be Base Customized Account Segment.
Case 3: If the value of the Account Segment Number is larger than 0, and there is a table containing the basic information of the customized account segment, the field value should be the table's name, such as Base Customer.

The Base Business Segment and the Base Business Segment Hierarchy have been designed to tabularize the portions of an organizational chart that is reflected in the business transactions as structural units e.g. business unit, department, cost center and project).
Code for each business segment.
Name of the business segment.
Relative level of the segment, with 1 being the consolidated level and the numbers increasing through the lower levels of the organizational chart.
Indicates the name of the organization type (e.g. department, cost centre).

Contains additional information about the sources provided in the GL Details table. Each source shall include a description of the ERP system or accounting package, from which the data is extracted, and information related to the business process the data represents.

Code for the posting source (code for the source from which the journal entry originated).\nEXAMPLE   Sales journal, cash receipts journal, general journal, payroll journal, accountant manual entry, spreadsheet.\nThe code shall be a unique indicator for the underlying source.
Description of the source system.

Description of the subledger or ERP module from which the journal entry originated.\nThis should tie back to a system or significant accounting process. In some instances, it can be represented by the source system.
Indicates whether the journal entry is system-generated or manually-entered.\nEXAMPLE   S is system-generated, M is manually-entered.
Major class of transaction associated with a business process.\nEXAMPLE   Sales.
Sub-process of a major business process.\nEXAMPLE   Orders, returns, discounts.
